subject: rbd: clean up unused parents of clones on deletion
commit_message:
rbd: clean up unused parents of clones on deletion

In order to make snapshotting ephemeral disks stored in rbd efficient
and avoid any local disk use, nova will tell glance about an rbd
snapshot's location rather than uploading data.

Since rbd images with snapshots cannot be deleted, nova cannot remove
the original disk in this case. Instead, nova renames the original rbd
image so glance can determine that it is no longer used by
nova. Glance can then delete this rbd image once its snapshots are
deleted.

To effect this, modify the rbd store's backend to recursively delete
any parents that have a special string in their name. This has no
chance of name collision from other openstack use since rbd images are
otherwise only named with uuids.

If an image based on a vm is deleted while the vm is still running,
only delete the parent snapshot, not the whole vm image. Rename
_delete_image() to _cleanup_image(), and add _cleanup_parent() to
determine when deleting the parent is safe.

To allow glance to handle this, it needs write access to the ceph pool
used by nova ephemeral disks.

DocImpact
Partial-Bug: #1346525
Signed-off-by: Josh Durgin <josh.durgin@inktank.com>

ASG scaling account for cooldown timestamp & in-progress

There are cases where it takes a long time to create a new resource as
requested by the scaling operation on an ASG resource, for instance, a
nova server creation followed by a complex SoftwareDeployment. During
this process, additional alarms may come in but failed to be blocked
by the current cooldown checking mechanism because the very first
timestamp has yet to be generated. This is leading to unexpected size
adjustment to the ASG.

This patch augments the existing cooldown checking mechanism with a
scaling-in-progress test so that additional alarms arriving during
the very first scaling operation will be ignored.

commit_message:
Fix Python 3 issues in the blockbridge driver

* Replace httplib import with six.moves.http_client
* Replace urllib imports with six.moves.urllib, update urllib.
  For example, replace urllib.quote() with urllib.parse.quote().
* test_blockbridge: try get the mock module from unittest.mock, part of

  bug on Python 3.4.
* On Python 3, base64.encodestring() expects bytes and returns bytes.
  Encode credentials to UTF-8 and decode base64 from ASCII to get the

subject: Docker container-create fails with Unicode is not supported
commit_message:
Docker container-create fails with Unicode is not supported

Problem description:
If a docker swarm baymodel, docker swarm bay, and docker container are
created according to instructions listed in the Magnum quick-start guide
(magnum/doc/source/dev/dev-quickstart.rst), then the container-create
operation fails with the following error:

   ERROR: Docker internal Error: decoding Unicode is not supported (HTTP 500)

The root cause is that the container image name is being passed as a
unicode value (e.g. u'cirros') to the docker conductor handler's
container_create() method, and this in turn is passed to _encode_utf8().
In _encode_utf8(), it's assumed that a string is being passed in, so a
conversion to unicode is attempted by passing the (unicode) image name
to six.u(). However, six.u() does not support unicode conversion of
unicode objects.

Fix description:
Make the _encode_utf8() method more resilient by allowing both string and
unicode arguments. Only do the intermediate conversion to unicode for
string arguments.

Change-Id: Ie60099172c4b6fa83c0d5d10aba0f9c24a349106
Closes-Bug: #1471984

subject: Added a 'NAME' attribute to define names of classes
commit_message:
Added a 'NAME' attribute to define names of classes

The need to redefine the typenames of versioned object is a common
usecase, which may be required either to make object name differ from
the python's classname or to give a same name to two different types to
indicates their duck-type compatibility.

The existing way of doing this is to override obj_name() classmethod of
VersionedObject class to return a needed string constant instead of
cls.__name__. However, such an override has a bad sideeffect: all the
descendants of such a class will have the same string constant as their
names as well, while this is most probably not needed.

This patch adds an alternative way to define the type name of the
versioned object: adding a 'NAME' attribute to appropriate class.
This attribute is used to compute the obj_name value, but only if the
attribute is defined at this particular class (i.e. is not inherited
from base).

The old way of overriding the obj_name() is still available for
backwards compatibility purposes but is not recommended for usage unless
it is required to have all the descendants to have the same obj_name
with their parent.

Change-Id: I4973aec459cdd49972b062132d0367e853b33caa

subject: Retry volume detach on DiskNotFound
commit_message:
Retry volume detach on DiskNotFound

When starting/restarting/rebuilding instances, it may happen that a
volume detach request comes right in the middle of attaching a volume
in the driver. In this case the hypervisor (e.g. libvirt) will throw
DiskNotFound exception in driver.detach_volume() call, but still
the volume gets attached eventually, when the instance starts.

This leaves the instance in the state, when the volume is `de-facto`
attached to it (i.e. shown in the `virsh dumpxmp $instance` output
for libvirt), but both Nova and Cinder think the volume is actually
*not* in-use.

The proposed solution is to give the hypervisor a chance to detach
the volume again when handling DiskNotFound exception as it must be
attached from what we know from the state of Cinder/Nova databases.

Closes-Bug: #1471271

Change-Id: I34dd207aa5de86b9f58b01fc6949692f6f9b64f2

subject: Add Puppetfile and install script
commit_message:
Add Puppetfile and install script

This repo will be cloned by the puppet modules and used to install
modules in functional tests. The script uses r10k to deploy modules
from the Puppetfile because this is the Puppet Labs recommended way to
manage puppet environments, and it is a popular method among our users.
We install all modules from git, not the forge, because r10k does not
give us dependency resolution so installing from the forge does not buy
us anything. If the modules have stable branches in git, r10k uses the
stable branch as a ref, otherwise it uses a tag (pinning to a specific
release).

If zuul-cloner is available, the script first installs the external
modules with r10k, then extracts the OpenStack modules from the
Puppetfile to install with zuul-cloner. In the future, this part may be
split out into a JJB job.

Note: because r10k purges the modules directory before installing
modules, and this feature cannot be turned off[1], we must run r10k to
install the external modules before running zuul-cloner to install the
OpenStack modules.

[1] https://github.com/puppetlabs/r10k/issues/172

subject: Fix log traces induced by retry decorator
commit_message:
Fix log traces induced by retry decorator

Patch 4e77442d5 added a retry decorator to the API layer
to catch DB deadlock errors. However, when they occur, the
retried operation ends up being ineffective because the original
body has been altered, which leads the notification and validation
layers to barf exceptions due to unrecognized/unserializable elements.

This ultimately results to an error reported to the user.

To address this, let's make a deep copy of the request body, before
we pass it down to the lower layers. This allows the decorator to
work on a pristine copy of the body on every attempt. The performance
impact for this should be negligible.

Closes-bug: #1470615

subject: Use alarm's evaluation periods in sufficient test
commit_message:
Use alarm's evaluation periods in sufficient test

Currently, we use constant value quorum=1 to check if there are enough
datapoints, however, this is not quite right for an alarm rule.

Image evaluation periods is set to, for i.e., 3 for an instance on
cpu_util greater or equal than 80%. Here are the cases which current
may not work as expected:

1. when system start or instance is just created, we may only get one
or two samples for the instance
2. when system is somewhere broken, or an instance is restarted (after
being shutoff), sample may fail to be collected in some time, so we only
get one or two sample in that time range

We want to avoid a spurious data peak, for example, instance cpu_util can
be 50%, 50%, 50%, 90%, in such case, alarm will not be triggered, but if
instance cpu_util is None, None, None, 90%, current code will think alarm
should be triggered, which is not consistent and may confuse end users.

This patch will put alarm to insufficient data when datapoints are less
than evaluation periods.

        ceilometer/alarm/evaluator/threshold.py

NOTE(mriedem): The conflict is due to the oslo.i18n imports on master
and oslo.i18n wasn't used in stable/juno so the _LW usage is removed.

subject: Avoid dead loop when update combination alarm
commit_message:
Avoid dead loop when update combination alarm

Dead loop scenario:
1. assume we have threhold alarm C, D
2. then we create combination alarm A with alarm_ids = C, D
3. and we create combination alarm B with alarm_ids = A
4. then we update alarm A with alarm_ids = B
5. then when evaluator alarm state, the two combination alarm is a dead loop

We should avoid such scenario

The basic idea is the following:
* all threshold alarms are good alarms, which definitely have no dependency,
  so there is no dead loop
* all alarms depending only on good alarms are good alarms

NOTE: This patch forbids updating alarm which will cause dead loop even though
it is disabled.

NOTE: If old environment already has dead loop combination alarms, after
upgrade with this patch, put /alarms/{id} api may not work util dead loop is
removed.

Change-Id: Ic4065db9243fb209026e6f5b154e19a705992607
